title: Dealing with the estate of someone who's died

body.content:
[After a person dies](/after-a-death), their property, money and possessions (their 'estate') must be given out according to either:

- the person’s will if they made one
- the law of [intestacy](/inherits-someone-dies-without-will) if they didn't

Before this can happen, the [person who deals with the estate](/estate-probate/who-deals-with-the-estate) needs to complete 3 tasks.

s1. [Value the estate](/estate-probate/tell-organisations), tell HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) and pay any Inheritance Tax the estate owes. Most estates aren’t taxed.
s2. [Get probate](/estate-probate/apply-probate) - the legal right to deal with the estate.
s3. Collect assets, pay debts and correctly [distribute the estate](/estate-probate/distribute-the-estate).

You don’t need to deal with the estate straight away after someone dies. There are only deadlines if there’s Inheritance Tax to pay.

Banks and other organisations usually need to be given a grant of probate (proof that you have the right to deal with the estate) before they'll release assets. But money in a joint account and property owned under a '[joint tenancy](/joint-property-ownership)' automatically pass to the other owner.

^There’s a different process in [Scotland](https://www.scotcourts.gov.uk/taking-action/dealing-with-a-deceased%27s-estate-in-scotland) and [Northern Ireland.](http://www.nidirect.gov.uk/applying-for-probate-in-northern-ireland)

##How long it takes

The process usually takes 6 to 9 months, or longer for big or complicated estates (for example if they involve trusts or there's tax to pay).

[Money Advice Service](https://www.moneyadviceservice.org.uk/en/articles/when-should-you-use-a-probate-specialist) has guidance on how and when to get help, including the costs of hiring a professional.

##Deadlines if there's Inheritance Tax to pay

If the estate owes Inheritance Tax, you’ll need to:

- send Inheritance Tax forms within one year
- start [paying tax](/paying-inheritance-tax/) by the end of the sixth month after the death - you can make a payment [before you finish valuing the estate](/paying-inheritance-tax/pay-early)

^[Estimate the estate's value](/estate-probate/estimate-estate-value) so you can work out if there's tax to pay.

##When you might not need probate

You may not need the legal right to deal with an estate if it both:

- passes automatically to the surviving spouse or civil partner because all the assets were held jointly
- doesn't include property, shares or land

The bank or other organisation holding the money may ask for proof of death, such as a copy of the death certificate.

^Each financial institution has its own rules - you may still need to apply for probate.^

After a person dies, their property, money and possessions (their ‘estate’) must be given out according to either:

  • the person’s will if they made one
  • the law of intestacy if they didn’t

Before this can happen, the person who deals with the estate needs to complete 3 tasks.

  1. Value the estate, tell HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) and pay any Inheritance Tax the estate owes. Most estates aren’t taxed.

  2. Get probate - the legal right to deal with the estate.

  3. Collect assets, pay debts and correctly distribute the estate.

You don’t need to deal with the estate straight away after someone dies. There are only deadlines if there’s Inheritance Tax to pay.

Banks and other organisations usually need to be given a grant of probate (proof that you have the right to deal with the estate) before they’ll release assets. But money in a joint account and property owned under a ‘joint tenancy’ automatically pass to the other owner.

There’s a different process in Scotland and Northern Ireland.

How long it takes

The process usually takes 6 to 9 months, or longer for big or complicated estates (for example if they involve trusts or there’s tax to pay).

Money Advice Service has guidance on how and when to get help, including the costs of hiring a professional.

Deadlines if there’s Inheritance Tax to pay

If the estate owes Inheritance Tax, you’ll need to:

  • send Inheritance Tax forms within one year
  • start paying tax by the end of the sixth month after the death - you can make a payment before you finish valuing the estate

Estimate the estate’s value so you can work out if there’s tax to pay.

When you might not need probate

You may not need the legal right to deal with an estate if it both:

  • passes automatically to the surviving spouse or civil partner because all the assets were held jointly
  • doesn’t include property, shares or land

The bank or other organisation holding the money may ask for proof of death, such as a copy of the death certificate.

Each financial institution has its own rules - you may still need to apply for probate.

parts.title: Who can deal with the estate

body.content:
Who applies for probate depends on whether the person who died left a will. There are a number of places you can check to [find the will](/search-will-probate).

##If there’s a will

You can apply for probate if you’re named in the will as the person who should deal with the estate (the ‘executor’). 

If you’re not willing or able to apply, and there aren’t any other named executors, [contact your local probate office](https://courttribunalfinder.service.gov.uk/search/postcode?aol=Probate) to find out what to do.

##If the person didn’t leave a will

You can usually apply for probate as the ‘administrator’ if you're the person's next of kin, for example their spouse, civil partner or child. The administrator is the person who deals with the estate if there’s no will.

If you're the partner of the person but weren't their husband, wife or civil partner when they died, you can't apply for probate. You're also not entitled to any of your partner's estate, unless you're able to [make changes to the inheritance](/alter-a-will-after-a-death).

###Work out who inherits the estate

The law decides who inherits the estate if there's no will. 

You can use a tool to [work out who'll inherit](/inherits-someone-dies-without-will). You’ll need this information to [find out if there's Inheritance Tax to pay](/estate-probate/estimate-estate-value) and when reporting the estate's value.

##Getting help with probate

Dealing with someone’s estate can be complicated. It usually takes 6 to 9 months to complete - or longer for big or complicated estates (for example if they involve trusts or owe tax).

You’re legally responsible for dealing with the estate correctly. You also need to:

- contact many organisations, people and government departments
- make calculations about the estate’s value 
- keep good records - you'll need these to produce [final estate accounts](/estate-probate/distribute-the-estate)

###Hiring a professional

You can hire a professional (for example a solicitor) to help with some or all of the tasks when dealing with an estate. 

Money Advice Service has guidance on [when and how to hire a professional.](https://www.moneyadviceservice.org.uk/en/articles/when-should-you-use-a-probate-specialist) Law Donut has advice on [keeping solicitors' fees down.](http://www.lawdonut.co.uk/personal/law/probate-executors-and-estate-administration/probate-and-estate-administration-faqs#PROEA22)

^You can also get help by calling the [probate and Inheritance Tax helpline](/government/organisations/hm-revenue-customs/contact/probate-and-inheritance-tax-enquiries).

Who applies for probate depends on whether the person who died left a will. There are a number of places you can check to find the will.

If there’s a will

You can apply for probate if you’re named in the will as the person who should deal with the estate (the ‘executor’).

If you’re not willing or able to apply, and there aren’t any other named executors, contact your local probate office to find out what to do.

If the person didn’t leave a will

You can usually apply for probate as the ‘administrator’ if you’re the person’s next of kin, for example their spouse, civil partner or child. The administrator is the person who deals with the estate if there’s no will.

If you’re the partner of the person but weren’t their husband, wife or civil partner when they died, you can’t apply for probate. You’re also not entitled to any of your partner’s estate, unless you’re able to make changes to the inheritance.

Work out who inherits the estate

The law decides who inherits the estate if there’s no will.

You can use a tool to work out who’ll inherit. You’ll need this information to find out if there’s Inheritance Tax to pay and when reporting the estate’s value.

Getting help with probate

Dealing with someone’s estate can be complicated. It usually takes 6 to 9 months to complete - or longer for big or complicated estates (for example if they involve trusts or owe tax).

You’re legally responsible for dealing with the estate correctly. You also need to:

  • contact many organisations, people and government departments
  • make calculations about the estate’s value
  • keep good records - you’ll need these to produce final estate accounts

Hiring a professional

You can hire a professional (for example a solicitor) to help with some or all of the tasks when dealing with an estate.

Money Advice Service has guidance on when and how to hire a professional. Law Donut has advice on keeping solicitors’ fees down.

You can also get help by calling the probate and Inheritance Tax helpline.

parts.title: Contact organisations about assets and debts

body.content:
To help you [value the estate](/estate-probate/estimate-estate-value) of the person who died, write to organisations to find out about the person's:

- assets, for example banks and pension providers
- debts, such as utility companies, mortgage lenders and credit card companies

In your letter:

- ask for the value of the asset or debt when the person died
- include a copy of the death certificate

##Which organisations to contact

Find organisations to contact about the person’s assets and debts by searching through their papers. You can also ask friends, family and any solicitor or accountant they had. 

Organisations that hold a person's assets often include:

- their bank
- their pension provider - ask if you should include any private pension when you [value the estate](/estate-probate/estimate-estate-value)
- their employer - the person may be owed wages
- any companies they held shares in - include the number of shares, company details and the share certificate number (if you have it)
- National Savings and Investments (NS&I) for Premium Bonds - use the [free tracing service](http://www.nsandi.com/how-do-i-track-down-unclaimed-or-forgotten-investments-with-nsi) if you can't find certificates
- other organisations that hold assets like ISAs, shares, investments or [assets in a trust](/guidance/trusts-and-inheritance-tax#dealing-with-a-trust-when-someone-dies)
- their landlord, if they had one - the person may have paid rent in advance

In your letter to the bank, also ask for:

- any standing orders and direct debits to be stopped (or transferred if they were in a joint name)
- a list of any share certificates or deeds they were holding for the person who died 

###If the person had a mortgage

Ask the mortgage lender if they require payments to continue while you're applying for probate. If they do, you need to either:

- pay these bills yourself - and reclaim them from the estate once you've got probate
- check if the person had a life assurance or mortgage protection policy that covers these payments

To help you value the estate of the person who died, write to organisations to find out about the person’s:

  • assets, for example banks and pension providers
  • debts, such as utility companies, mortgage lenders and credit card companies

In your letter:

  • ask for the value of the asset or debt when the person died
  • include a copy of the death certificate

Which organisations to contact

Find organisations to contact about the person’s assets and debts by searching through their papers. You can also ask friends, family and any solicitor or accountant they had.

Organisations that hold a person’s assets often include:

  • their bank
  • their pension provider - ask if you should include any private pension when you value the estate
  • their employer - the person may be owed wages
  • any companies they held shares in - include the number of shares, company details and the share certificate number (if you have it)
  • National Savings and Investments (NS&I) for Premium Bonds - use the free tracing service if you can’t find certificates
  • other organisations that hold assets like ISAs, shares, investments or assets in a trust
  • their landlord, if they had one - the person may have paid rent in advance

In your letter to the bank, also ask for:

  • any standing orders and direct debits to be stopped (or transferred if they were in a joint name)
  • a list of any share certificates or deeds they were holding for the person who died

If the person had a mortgage

Ask the mortgage lender if they require payments to continue while you’re applying for probate. If they do, you need to either:

  • pay these bills yourself - and reclaim them from the estate once you’ve got probate
  • check if the person had a life assurance or mortgage protection policy that covers these payments

Before you can apply for probate, you need an estimate of the estate’s value.

You need this to find out if there’s Inheritance Tax to pay. This will affect how you report the estate's value, and the deadlines for reporting and paying any tax.

The estate won't have to pay tax as long as it either:

- all passes to the dead person's spouse or civil partner, or to charity (or organisations like museums or community amateur sports clubs)
- has a value below £325,000 - if the person who died was widowed, this might [increase to £650,000](/inheritance-tax/leaving-assets-spouse-civil-partner)

^If you already know whether there’s tax to pay, you don't need to estimate the value. You can go straight to [reporting the estate’s value](/estate-probate/tell-hmrc-estate-value).

##Working out your estimate

You need to estimate the 'gross' value of the estate. This is the value of the assets plus 'gifts'.

^Gifts are certain assets (for example cash) given away in the 7 years before the person died.

At this stage, your estimate only needs to be accurate enough for you to know if the estate owes tax.  

###Assets

Start by listing the person’s assets - the things the person owned with a value. 

These may include:

- assets held by [organisations you've written to](/estate-probate/tell-organisations) - such as money in the person's bank account, pension or investments
- possessions - for example their house, jewellery, furniture or car
- payments when they died - for example life insurance or a lump sum ‘death benefit’ from a pension

Then estimate the value of each on the date the person died. Use the asset’s realistic selling price on the open market.

###Valuing joint assets

Divide the value of the asset by 2 if it was owned jointly with the person’s spouse or civil partner.

For property or land shared with others, divide the value by the number of owners. You can then take 10% off the share of the person who died. In Scotland, take £4,000 off the value of the whole asset before working out their share instead.

If the person jointly owned property as a [tenant in common](/joint-property-ownership), work out the value based on the person's share.

^Some bank accounts are in joint names for convenience only, for example if an elderly person added their child to help them with the account. When valuing the account, use the amount the person actually owned, rather than dividing by the number of owners.

###Gifts

Check bank statements or contact family members to find out about gifts of cash or other assets:

- in the 7 years before the person died if they totalled £3,000 or more per year - don't include [exempt gifts](/inheritance-tax/gifts), such as those for birthdays or weddings
- at any time if they continued to benefit from a gift (for example they [gave a house away](/inheritance-tax/passing-on-home) but lived in it rent-free) or [put a gift in a trust](/guidance/trusts-and-inheritance-tax)

To estimate the value of each gift, use either:

+ the approximate market value (realistic selling price) of the gift when it was made
+ the realistic selling price of the gift when the deceased stopped benefitting from it (if they benefitted from the gift after giving it away)

^If the person gave away more than £325,000 before they died, the recipients may have to pay [Inheritance Tax on their gifts](/inheritance-tax/gifts).

##Debts

Don’t include the estate's debts when you estimate the gross value - but you'll need to tell HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) about them when you report the value of the estate.

Check for records of debts when the person died, for example:

- their mortgage, loans, credit cards or overdrafts
- ‘liabilities’ like household bills or bills for goods or services they’d received but not yet paid for (like building work, decorators, accountants)

##Get the gross value of the estate

Add the assets to any gifts to get the gross value. Ignore the debts at this stage.

You can now [start telling HMRC about the value of the estate](/estate-probate/tell-hmrc-estate-value).


*[NS&I]: National Savings and Investments
*[HMRC]: HM Revenue and Customs

You need this to find out if there’s Inheritance Tax to pay. This will affect how you report the estate’s value, and the deadlines for reporting and paying any tax.

The estate won’t have to pay tax as long as it either:

  • all passes to the dead person’s spouse or civil partner, or to charity (or organisations like museums or community amateur sports clubs)

If you already know whether there’s tax to pay, you don’t need to estimate the value. You can go straight to reporting the estate’s value.

Working out your estimate

You need to estimate the ‘gross’ value of the estate. This is the value of the assets plus ‘gifts’.

Gifts are certain assets (for example cash) given away in the 7 years before the person died.

At this stage, your estimate only needs to be accurate enough for you to know if the estate owes tax.

Assets

Start by listing the person’s assets - the things the person owned with a value.

These may include:

  • assets held by organisations you’ve written to - such as money in the person’s bank account, pension or investments
  • possessions - for example their house, jewellery, furniture or car
  • payments when they died - for example life insurance or a lump sum ‘death benefit’ from a pension

Then estimate the value of each on the date the person died. Use the asset’s realistic selling price on the open market.

Valuing joint assets

Divide the value of the asset by 2 if it was owned jointly with the person’s spouse or civil partner.

For property or land shared with others, divide the value by the number of owners. You can then take 10% off the share of the person who died. In Scotland, take £4,000 off the value of the whole asset before working out their share instead.

If the person jointly owned property as a tenant in common, work out the value based on the person’s share.

Some bank accounts are in joint names for convenience only, for example if an elderly person added their child to help them with the account. When valuing the account, use the amount the person actually owned, rather than dividing by the number of owners.

Gifts

Check bank statements or contact family members to find out about gifts of cash or other assets:

  • in the 7 years before the person died if they totalled £3,000 or more per year - don’t include exempt gifts, such as those for birthdays or weddings
  • at any time if they continued to benefit from a gift (for example they gave a house away but lived in it rent-free) or put a gift in a trust

To estimate the value of each gift, use either:

  • the approximate market value (realistic selling price) of the gift when it was made
  • the realistic selling price of the gift when the deceased stopped benefitting from it (if they benefitted from the gift after giving it away)

If the person gave away more than £325,000 before they died, the recipients may have to pay Inheritance Tax on their gifts.

Debts

Don’t include the estate’s debts when you estimate the gross value - but you’ll need to tell HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) about them when you report the value of the estate.

Check for records of debts when the person died, for example:

  • their mortgage, loans, credit cards or overdrafts
  • ‘liabilities’ like household bills or bills for goods or services they’d received but not yet paid for (like building work, decorators, accountants)

Get the gross value of the estate

Add the assets to any gifts to get the gross value. Ignore the debts at this stage.

You can now start telling HMRC about the value of the estate.

parts.title: Report the estate's value to HMRC

body.content:
When you've [estimated the value of the estate](/estate-probate/estimate-estate-value) you can: - start reporting the value in detail to HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) - you'll find out whether you can report everything online or if you'll need a paper form - find out if there's tax to pay and when to pay it This process usually takes a few months to complete. You can save and return to the online form.

Report the estate's value


##Before you start You need to: - know who will inherit the estate's assets - get this from the will, or [check the law](/inherits-someone-dies-without-will) if there isn't one - have an [estimate of the gross value of the estate](/estate-probate/estimate-estate-value) - have [told organisations that the person has died](/estate-probate/tell-organisations) - you'll need this to give accurate valuations of the person's assets or debts As part of telling HMRC about the estate, you work out its detailed 'net' value - this is assets plus gifts minus debts. You'll need to know the net value when you [apply for probate](/estate-probate/apply-for-probate). ###Getting more accurate valuations When telling HMRC about Inheritance Tax, you’ll usually need more accurate valuations of the estate. This includes using a professional valuer for things over £500. You can continue using estimates if: - the estate's gross value is less than £250,000 - all the estate passes to the dead person's spouse or civil partner, a charity or organisations like museums or community amateur sports clubs ##If you need help Call the [probate and Inheritance Tax helpline](/government/organisations/hm-revenue-customs/contact/probate-and-inheritance-tax-enquiries). *[HMRC]: HM Revenue and Customs

When you’ve estimated the value of the estate you can:

  • start reporting the value in detail to HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) - you’ll find out whether you can report everything online or if you’ll need a paper form
  • find out if there’s tax to pay and when to pay it

This process usually takes a few months to complete. You can save and return to the online form.

Report the estate's value


Before you start

You need to:

  • know who will inherit the estate’s assets - get this from the will, or check the law if there isn’t one
  • have an estimate of the gross value of the estate
  • have told organisations that the person has died - you’ll need this to give accurate valuations of the person’s assets or debts

As part of telling HMRC about the estate, you work out its detailed ‘net’ value - this is assets plus gifts minus debts. You’ll need to know the net value when you apply for probate.

Getting more accurate valuations

When telling HMRC about Inheritance Tax, you’ll usually need more accurate valuations of the estate. This includes using a professional valuer for things over £500.

You can continue using estimates if:

  • the estate’s gross value is less than £250,000
  • all the estate passes to the dead person’s spouse or civil partner, a charity or organisations like museums or community amateur sports clubs

If you need help

Call the probate and Inheritance Tax helpline.

Once you've [reported the value of the estate to HMRC](/tell-hmrc-estate-value), you can apply for a grant of probate. 

To apply, fill in [form PA1.](http://hmctsformfinder.justice.gov.uk/HMCTS/GetForm.do?court_forms_id=735) 

^You apply in a different way in [Scotland](/government/publications/inheritance-tax-confirmation-c1) and [Northern Ireland.](http://www.nidirect.gov.uk/applying-for-probate-in-northern-ireland)

[Probate may not be needed](/estate-probate/overview) for some estates.

##Sending your application

Send your completed PA1 form to your local [probate office.](https://courttribunalfinder.service.gov.uk/search/postcode?aol=Probate) You should use registered post or take the documents in person.

You also need to include:

- an official copy of the [death certificate](/after-a-death/register-the-death)
- the original will and 3 copies - including any additions or amendments to it ('codicils')
- the application fee of £215 - send a cheque made payable to HM Courts and Tribunals Service (there's no fee if the estate is under £5,000)
- the fee for any extra copies of the grant (50p each) - this means you can send them to different organisations at the same time
- any paper Inheritance Tax forms you needed to fill in

^Keep a copy of the documents for your own records.

##After you've applied

Before you get the grant, you need to swear an oath. This a promise that the information you've given is true to the best of your knowledge and that you'll distribute the estate correctly. 

The probate office will send you an oath and details of how to arrange an appointment. You'll need to swear the oath at either:

- the office of a commissioner for oaths (usually a solicitor)  
- a local probate office

Once you've sworn the oath and signed the will, you should get the grant through the post within 10 working days.

^Anyone can pay to [view the will or grant of probate](/search-will-probate) once you've sworn the oath.

##If you need help
Call the [probate and Inheritance Tax helpline](/government/organisations/hm-revenue-customs/contact/probate-and-inheritance-tax-enquiries).

Once you’ve reported the value of the estate to HMRC, you can apply for a grant of probate.

To apply, fill in form PA1.

You apply in a different way in Scotland and Northern Ireland.

Probate may not be needed for some estates.

Sending your application

Send your completed PA1 form to your local probate office. You should use registered post or take the documents in person.

You also need to include:

  • an official copy of the death certificate
  • the original will and 3 copies - including any additions or amendments to it (‘codicils’)
  • the application fee of £215 - send a cheque made payable to HM Courts and Tribunals Service (there’s no fee if the estate is under £5,000)
  • the fee for any extra copies of the grant (50p each) - this means you can send them to different organisations at the same time
  • any paper Inheritance Tax forms you needed to fill in

Keep a copy of the documents for your own records.

After you’ve applied

Before you get the grant, you need to swear an oath. This a promise that the information you’ve given is true to the best of your knowledge and that you’ll distribute the estate correctly.

The probate office will send you an oath and details of how to arrange an appointment. You’ll need to swear the oath at either:

  • the office of a commissioner for oaths (usually a solicitor)
  • a local probate office

Once you’ve sworn the oath and signed the will, you should get the grant through the post within 10 working days.

Anyone can pay to view the will or grant of probate once you’ve sworn the oath.

If you need help

Call the probate and Inheritance Tax helpline.

Once you've been given the [grant of probate](/estate-probate/apply-probate), there are things you need to do before you distribute the estate to the beneficiaries (the people who will inherit the assets).

s1. Open a bank account on behalf of the estate to pay money from assets into. You can also use it to pay any debts or liabilities.
s2. Send a copy of the grant to organisations that hold the dead person's assets, for example their bank.
s3. When the assets have been released, transfer them into the estate's bank account.
s4. Pay off any debts or outstanding payments from the estate's account, like outstanding bills or Inheritance Tax owed. Ask for a 'receipt of settlement' - you'll need this for the final accounts.
s5. If you think there are creditors (people owed money) or beneficiaries that you don't know about, place a notice in [The Gazette](https://www.thegazette.co.uk/wills-and-probate/place-a-deceased-estates-notice) (or [The Scotsman](http://scotsman.adperfect.com/) if the deceased lived in Scotland). You won't be personally responsible for any claims that come in from 2 months after the notice is published.
s6. You can then distribute the estate to the beneficiaries  as detailed in the will, or by the law [if there's no will](/inherits-someone-dies-without-will). You must pay off any debts before you do this.


##Prepare the final accounts

You must show how you distributed the estate's assets in the final accounts.

Include relevant documents, for example:

- written confirmation that beneficiaries received their share of the estate
- receipts showing debts paid, like utility bills
- receipts for your expenses from dealing with the estate
- letters from HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC), if the estate paid Inheritance Tax

Send copies of the final accounts to the beneficiaries. These must be approved and signed by you and each beneficiary.

###Other records to keep

As well as the final accounts, keep copies of any:

- will
- signed Inheritance Tax forms and supporting documents
- records showing how you worked out the value of assets, for example an estate agent’s valuation

You must keep all the paperwork for at least 5 years after distributing the assets. Keep it for longer if there's a surviving spouse or civil partner.

##Tax paid by beneficiaries

Beneficiaries don’t usually pay [tax on things they inherit](/tax-property-money-shares-you-inherit) at the time they inherit them.

##If you need help
Call the [probate and Inheritance Tax helpline](/government/organisations/hm-revenue-customs/contact/probate-and-inheritance-tax-enquiries).

*[HMRC]: HM Revenue and Customs

Once you’ve been given the grant of probate, there are things you need to do before you distribute the estate to the beneficiaries (the people who will inherit the assets).

  1. Open a bank account on behalf of the estate to pay money from assets into. You can also use it to pay any debts or liabilities.

  2. Send a copy of the grant to organisations that hold the dead person’s assets, for example their bank.

  3. When the assets have been released, transfer them into the estate’s bank account.

  4. Pay off any debts or outstanding payments from the estate’s account, like outstanding bills or Inheritance Tax owed. Ask for a ‘receipt of settlement’ - you’ll need this for the final accounts.

  5. If you think there are creditors (people owed money) or beneficiaries that you don’t know about, place a notice in The Gazette (or The Scotsman if the deceased lived in Scotland). You won’t be personally responsible for any claims that come in from 2 months after the notice is published.

  6. You can then distribute the estate to the beneficiaries as detailed in the will, or by the law if there’s no will. You must pay off any debts before you do this.

Prepare the final accounts

You must show how you distributed the estate’s assets in the final accounts.

Include relevant documents, for example:

  • written confirmation that beneficiaries received their share of the estate
  • receipts showing debts paid, like utility bills
  • receipts for your expenses from dealing with the estate
  • letters from HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC), if the estate paid Inheritance Tax

Send copies of the final accounts to the beneficiaries. These must be approved and signed by you and each beneficiary.

Other records to keep

As well as the final accounts, keep copies of any:

  • will
  • signed Inheritance Tax forms and supporting documents
  • records showing how you worked out the value of assets, for example an estate agent’s valuation

You must keep all the paperwork for at least 5 years after distributing the assets. Keep it for longer if there’s a surviving spouse or civil partner.

Tax paid by beneficiaries

Beneficiaries don’t usually pay tax on things they inherit at the time they inherit them.

If you need help

Call the probate and Inheritance Tax helpline.

parts.title: If the estate received income while you dealt with it

body.content:
Once you've distributed the estate, tell HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) if the estate has to pay:

- [Income Tax](/income-tax) on things not taxed automatically, like rental income or income from savings or dividends 
- [Capital Gains Tax](/capital-gains-tax) if [certain assets](/capital-gains-tax/what-you-pay-it-on) were sold - special rules mean the estate only pays tax on gains made since the person died (not when the deceased bought the asset)

Include income and capital gains from when the person died up until the date you distributed their estate.

You pay tax on any savings income that's part of the estate - you don't get a tax-free savings allowance.

^You can [get help with tax](/tax-help).

##Telling HMRC

You can write to HMRC as long as the income or capital gains are small enough. In your letter tell them:

* the tax you think is due
* the name, address and National Insurance number of the person who died
* your name and contact details

Send your letter to [HMRC’s address for PAYE and Self Assessment](/government/organisations/hm-revenue-customs/contact/income-tax-enquiries-for-individuals-pensioners-and-employees).

HMRC will tell you how to pay any tax due.

###Reporting large income and capital gains

Instead of sending a letter, fill in the [trust and estate tax return](/government/publications/self-assessment-trust-and-estate-tax-return-sa900) if any of the following apply:

* the total [Income Tax](/income-tax) and [Capital Gains Tax](/capital-gains-tax) due is more than £10,000
* more than £500,000 of the estate's assets were sold in any one tax year
* the estate was worth more than £2.5 million at the date of death

To send a trust and estate tax return, you can either:

- fill in [paper form SA900](/government/publications/self-assessment-trust-and-estate-tax-return-sa900) and post it to HMRC by 31 October after the tax year it applies to
- buy [software](/software-tax-returns) to send it electronically by 31 January (3 months later)

After you’ve sent your return, HMRC will tell you how much the estate owes. You’ll need to [pay the Self Assessment bill](/pay-self-assessment-tax-bill) by the deadline.

##Income and gains from before the person died

As long as you’ve [told government organisations](/after-a-death/organisations-you-need-to-contact-and-tell-us-once) that the person has died, HMRC will contact you if you need to fill in a [Self Assessment tax return](/self-assessment-tax-returns). Only include income and gains from 6 April up to the date the person died.


*[HMRC]: HM Revenue and Customs

  • Income Tax on things not taxed automatically, like rental income or income from savings or dividends

Include income and capital gains from when the person died up until the date you distributed their estate.

You pay tax on any savings income that’s part of the estate - you don’t get a tax-free savings allowance.

HMRC will tell you how to pay any tax due.

Instead of sending a letter, fill in the trust and estate tax return if any of the following apply:

  • the total Income Tax and Capital Gains Tax due is more than £10,000
  • more than £500,000 of the estate’s assets were sold in any one tax year
  • the estate was worth more than £2.5 million at the date of death

To send a trust and estate tax return, you can either:

  • fill in paper form SA900 and post it to HMRC by 31 October after the tax year it applies to
  • buy software to send it electronically by 31 January (3 months later)

After you’ve sent your return, HMRC will tell you how much the estate owes. You’ll need to pay the Self Assessment bill by the deadline.
